sciknow-25x1-scientific-papers.title: Emerging artificial intelligence methods in structural engineering
sciknow-25x1-scientific-papers.abstract: Formal, machine-readable theories, taxonomy definitions, and connections to humanreadable language make up ontology, the formal specification of conceptualization. In addition to methodical definitions, it offers axioms that guide the interpretation of words. Many other sorts of relationships, both structural and nonstructural, including inheritance, generalization, aggregation, and instantiation, are supported by an ontology. It is necessary to handle a number of security issues, including identity management, cryptography, trust, application security, authentication, access control, and privacy. Access control is the process of maintaining resource privacy, project-based group membership, and role specificity in accordance with the goals of the ontology under the proposal. This research examines and contrasts three different ontology-based access control strategies: attribute-based access control (ABAC), context-based access control (CBAC), and role-based access control (RBAC). I-RBAC, BRBAC, SA-ODC and RBACSE are the RBAC approaches used for comparison. For analysing the CBAC procedure, ACAIA, CAHMS, CASPSA and FBCAAC algorithms are used. Finally for evaluating the ABAC method, OABAC, FABAC, AWS-IoTAC and ABAC-PHR algorithms are employed. CASPSA, CAHMS, ACAIA and FBCAAC has a data retrieval time of 1.8, 2.4, 6.1, and 9.4 s. IRBAC, BRBAC, SA-ODC and RBACSE has a turn around time of 66.3, 79.1, 150.5, and 177.2 s respectively. According to the experimental results, attribute based access control systems perform better for securing healthcare data.

sciknow-25x1-research-contexts.fieldOfStudy: Structural Engineering, Cloud Computing, Security in Healthcare Systems

underlyingTheories.relevance: This system uses an ontology-based approach, where people and their relationships can be represented to conceptually characterize PHR information in the cloud and to decide PHR access authorization for users.

guidingModels.relevance: Enhances the RBAC model by incorporating job responsibilities and related tasks, utilizing several learning agents and role design based on users' official jobs within an organization.
An auditable, adaptable, and scalable RBAC system built on the EOS blockchain to satisfy enterprise security needs.

guidingModels.modelName: SA-ODC (Security Aware Mechanism and Ontology Based Data Access Control)
guidingModels.relevance: Based on the secure awareness technique (SAT) and ontology-based data access control in cloud computing to ensure the security of medical data.

guidingModels.modelName: RBAC-HIS (Role-Based Access Control in Healthcare Information System)
guidingModels.relevance: Applies RBAC in the context of HIS, often in combination with MAC and DAC for added security levels.
A framework that uses semantic technologies to improve architectural requirements and middleware service requirements for IoT.

guidingModels.modelName: CAHMS (Context Aware Framework for Healthcare Monitoring System)
guidingModels.relevance: Focuses on monitoring the health or circumstances of a monitored element, using context history components and a reasoning engine.

guidingModels.modelName: CASPSA (Context Aware Security and Privacy as a Service in the IoT)
guidingModels.relevance: A design that integrates context awareness, adaptive security, and privacy into IoT applications.

guidingModels.modelName: FBCAAC (Fog Based Context Aware Access Control)
guidingModels.relevance: An updated platform for adaptable access control information from various sources in a fog computing context.
A model that includes unique IoT access control elements in addition to the fundamental cloud access control components.

guidingModels.modelName: OABAC (Ontology Driven Attribute Based Access Control)
guidingModels.relevance: A method for the semantic modelling of access control policies, particularly the setting of expressions that make up these rules.

guidingModels.modelName: FABAC (Formal Attribute Based Access Control System)
guidingModels.relevance: Allows the creation of fine-grained security policies and considers individual privacy preferences.

guidingModels.modelName: ABAC-PHR (Attribute-Based Access Control in E-Health Systems)
guidingModels.relevance: Provides a unified very fine access control mechanism in cloud computing for PHR.

sciknow-25x1-research-problems.problemStatement: The core research problem addressed in the paper is the need for effective and secure access control mechanisms in cloud computing environments, particularly for the management of patient health records (PHRs) in healthcare systems. The paper aims to examine and compare various ontology-based access control strategies, including attribute-based access control (ABAC), context-based access control (CBAC), and role-based access control (RBAC), to determine the most efficient method for securing healthcare data.
sciknow-25x1-research-problems.problemScope: The scope of the problem includes the security issues related to identity management, cryptography, trust, application security, authentication, access control, and privacy in cloud computing environments, with a focus on healthcare applications and the management of PHRs.
sciknow-25x1-research-problems.problemImportance: The problem is significant because ensuring the security and privacy of healthcare data, especially PHRs, is critical in the adoption of cloud computing services in the healthcare industry. Effective access control mechanisms are essential to protect sensitive health information from unauthorized access and potential security breaches.
sciknow-25x1-research-problems.businessRelevance: The research problem is relevant to businesses and the healthcare industry as it addresses the challenge of securing sensitive health data in cloud environments. Solving this problem has potential economic impact by increasing trust in cloud services for healthcare applications, thereby facilitating the digitalization of patient records and improving the efficiency of healthcare delivery.

sciknow-25x1-research-questions.questionText: How do various ontology-based access control strategies compare in terms of security and efficiency for securing healthcare data?
Which ontology-based access control strategy performs best for securing healthcare data?
What are the turnaround times for different Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) approaches used for comparison?
How do Context-Aware Access Control (CAAC) algorithms compare in terms of data retrieval time?
What is the ontology processing time for different Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC) algorithms?

sciknow-25x1-future-directions.directionDescription: The future work is focused on designing a new algorithm to secure healthcare data.

sciknow-25x1-potential-applications.applicationDescription: Securing healthcare data using ontology based data access control approaches such as role-based access control, context-aware access control, and attribute-based access control.
Application of ontology based data access control approaches in smart cities for enhancing security.
Utilization of ontology based data access control approaches in industries to improve security measures.

sciknow-25x1-methodological-frameworks.name: Emerging artificial intelligence methods in structural engineering
sciknow-25x1-methodological-frameworks.description: The paper presents a methodological framework for evaluating and comparing various ontology-based access control strategies in the context of securing healthcare data. The framework involves the analysis of three different ontology-driven techniques: role-based access control (RBAC), context-aware access control (CAAC), and attribute-based access control (ABAC). The study utilizes specific algorithms for each access control method and compares their performance based on metrics such as data retrieval time, ontology processing time, delay, and turn around time. The evaluation is conducted using Python and Matlab tools on a system with an Intel Core i5 CPU, an NVidia GeForce GTX 1650 GPU, a 16-bit operating system, and 16GB of RAM.

studyDesign.designDetails: The study involves a comparative analysis of different ontology-based access control strategies, specifically focusing on RBAC, CAAC, and ABAC methods. The comparison is based on the performance of specific algorithms representing each access control method.

procedures.procedureName: Comparative Analysis of Access Control Strategies

steps.description: Implement the algorithms representing each access control method: RBAC, CAAC, and ABAC.
steps.inputs: Access control strategies and their respective algorithms.

steps.description: Measure the performance of each algorithm using metrics such as data retrieval time, ontology processing time, delay, and turn around time.
Use Python and Matlab tools to analyze the data and compare the performance of the algorithms.
steps.outputs: Graphical representations and statistical analysis of the comparison.

procedures.procedureDescription: The procedure involves the evaluation of different access control strategies by implementing specific algorithms for each method and comparing their performance based on predefined metrics.

dataAnalysis.algorithmsUsed: Specific algorithms for RBAC, CAAC, and ABAC methods.
dataAnalysis.summary: The data analysis involves the use of Python and Matlab tools to process the performance data obtained from the implementation of the algorithms. The analysis includes the creation of graphical representations to compare the throughput, data retrieval time, received packets, delay, and turn around time for each access control method.

resultsRepresentation.summary: The results of the study are represented through tables and figures that illustrate the performance comparison of the various access control strategies. The tables provide detailed statistics for each algorithm, while the figures graphically depict the throughput and received packets metrics.

sciknow-25x1-material-tools.roleInProcedure: Used to drive nails into wood
